awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Smart Stent for Post-Endovascular Aneurysm Repair Surveillance
awd_abstract_narration:
An abdominal aortic aneurysm is the most commonly diagnosed arterial aneurysm that is an abnormal bulge on the aorta associated with the gradual thinning of the vessel wall. With mortality as high as 80% in cases of ruptures, abdominal aortic aneurysm accounts for more than 10,000 deaths in the United States every year. One of the most common treatments is endovascular aneurysm repair, which redirects blood flow away from the aortic wall and bypasses the weak spots by implanting a covered stent graft in the aneurysm sac via a minimally invasive procedure. Among the stent recipients, 30% of them can experience persistent blood flow into the aneurysm sac, called ‘endoleak,’ leading to aneurysm expansion and rupture. Thus, blood pressure and flow near the stent should be periodically monitored. However, the commonly used imaging technique is highly dependent on patient compliance, and its repeatedly administrated iodinated contrast poses a risk of chronic kidney disease. As such, the overall objective of this research is to create a Smart Stent based on a flexible and battery-less membrane-based sensor and wireless bioelectronics with a deep-learning algorithm to realize automated diagnosis of endoleak. This collaborative research will integrate the scientific findings and discoveries with educational venues for students across disciplines (Electrical and Mechanical Engineering), generations (K-12 to lifelong learners), and two institutes (Temple University and Kansas State University).

The overall objective of this research is to develop a Smart Stent for post-endovascular aneurysm repair surveillance that combines a flexible, and battery-less bioelectronic system with a deep-learning algorithm to realize automated diagnosis of endoleak. The central hypothesis is that Smart Stent, created by conformally weaving piezoelectric porous membrane sensors inside and outside of the conventional stent graft, will bring a novel electromechanical wireless biotelemetry scheme whose sensor data can be directly analyzed by a deep-learning model for classification of complex hemodynamics. The intellectual merits of the proposed research include 1) design of an auxetic porous piezoelectric membrane for the Smart Stent that is optimized for the multi-modal sensing of blood pressure and flow, 2) microfabrication  of complex 3D structure and surface-integrated micro coils for near-field magnetic induction communication, 3) a novel electromechanical interrogation scheme that converts energy from physiological information (e.g., blood pressure and flow) into wireless magnetic induction signals, 4) a comprehensive evaluation using a precise aneurysm phantom model to build baseline data for cardiovascular research, and 5) a deep learning-enabled sensing classification algorithm that offers real-time, quantitative, and automated assessment of five different types of endoleak. The research will establish a machine learning-enabled wireless sensing system that will spur new theory and understanding for the next generation implantable biomedical system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report for the General Public

Award Title: Collaborative Research: Smart Stent for Post-Endovascular Aneurysm Repair Surveillance

Federal Award ID: 2326938

This project aimed to develop an innovative Smart Stent for post-endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) surveillance to address critical challenges in monitoring abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) treatment. Abdominal aortic aneurysms, if left untreated, can rupture and lead to life-threatening complications. EVAR, a common preventive procedure, uses a stent graft to reinforce the weakened artery wall. However, post-EVAR complications, such as blood flow leakage into the aneurysm sac (endoleak), demand regular and invasive clinical monitoring using imaging techniques. This project resolves these challenges by introducing a Smart Stent capable of real-time, non-invasive, and wireless hemodynamic monitoring. This was achieved through the development of a porous piezoelectric membrane optimized for multi-modal sensing, the fabrication of a 3D-printed stent with integrated coils for wireless communication, and the validation of its performance in a simulated aneurysm model. These advancements reduce the reliance on frequent imaging, enable early detection of complications through automated data analysis, and improve patient outcomes while minimizing healthcare costs.

Intellectual Merit:

The Smart Stent integrates a porous piezoelectric membrane, 3D microfabrication techniques, and a machine learning-enabled diagnostic framework. One key achievement of the project was the development of a unique polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) membrane with engineered pore architectures, optimized for multi-modal sensing capabilities. These membranes enable precise measurement of blood pressure and flow within the aneurysm, forming the foundation for real-time hemodynamic sensing. Additionally, a three-dimensional (3D) porous piezoelectric hollow cylinder was designed and fabricated using advanced techniques such as laser micromachining and 3D printing. This stent integrates surface-coated coils that allow wireless, magnetic induction-based communication, facilitating non-invasive hemodynamic measurements. The wireless pressure-sensing capability of the stent was experimentally validated within a 3D-printed aneurysm phantom model, where the resonance frequency influenced by pressure changes was successfully measured through inductive coupling with an external antenna. Furthermore, the collected data was utilized to develop and test a deep-learning model for endoleak classification, showcasing the Smart Stent’s potential for automated diagnosis and an innovative approach to post-EVAR surveillance. Lastly, a novel method for directly printing piezoelectric smart stents using PVDF-TrFE material was investigated. These stents demonstrated the ability to harvest energy from mechanical stress, offering a promising pathway to self-powered sensing devices.

Broader Impacts:

This project addressed key healthcare challenges by introducing a transformative technology that improves patient outcomes and reduces healthcare costs. The Smart Stent enhances patient care by providing continuous and remote monitoring, reducing the need for frequent in-clinic visits and minimizing exposure to harmful imaging techniques such as CT scans. This innovation promotes long-term surveillance compliance among patients, thereby reducing the risk of undetected complications. Furthermore, the project contributed to the advancement of bioelectronic systems by integrating piezoelectric materials with wireless communication technology, paving the way for future implantable devices with similar capabilities. It also supported educational and workforce development by offering research and learning opportunities to graduate and undergraduate students at partner institutions. The project extended its impact through community outreach programs, including workshops aimed at fostering interest in STEM fields. Additionally, the Smart Stent demonstrates significant potential to lower healthcare costs by reducing the frequency of expensive diagnostic procedures, hospital visits, and treatments associated with undetected complications.

Summary:

Over the course of this project, we successfully demonstrated the feasibility of the Smart Stent as a novel bioelectronic device for post-EVAR surveillance. The project achieved significant outcomes, including the development and optimization of porous piezoelectric membranes for hemodynamic sensing, enabling precise and multi-modal monitoring of blood flow and pressure. A functional Smart Stent prototype was fabricated with wireless pressure-sensing capabilities, and its performance was validated in a 3D-printed aneurysm model under simulated physiological conditions. The project also explored self-energized stents using piezoelectric materials, demonstrating the feasibility of sustainable, long-term operation for implantable devices. These achievements establish the Smart Stent as a promising solution for addressing challenges in post-EVAR monitoring and lay the groundwork for further research and commercialization. The project highlights the intersection of biomedical engineering, materials science, and healthcare innovation, emphasizing its transformative potential to improve patient outcomes and advance medical technologies.

 


Last Modified: 02/04/2025
Modified by: Jungkwun Kim
